headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Sept. 18, 2010.

headline: Yanks 4, Orioles 3
summary: With the Yankees trailing by two runs and down to their final out, Alex Rodriguez hit a three-run homer in the ninth inning to power them to a 4-3 win over the Orioles Friday at Camden Yards.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: India This Week
summary: Some snapshots of events that were in the news in India this week (Sept. 11 - Sept. 19.)

headline: Pope Meets Abuse Victims in U.K.
summary: Pope Benedict XVI expressed "deep sorrow" to victims of clerical sex-abuse during a Mass and a meeting in his first visit to the U.K.

headline: Yom Kippur Around the World
summary: Jews in Israel and around the world began observing the start of the holiest day of the Jewish calendar, the 25 hours of fasting and contemplation known as Yom Kippur.

headline: Greek Opposition Leader Rips Rivals
summary: Greece's main opposition leader Antonis Samaras said Saturday that the socialist government has mishandled the economy with a wrong policy mix, but it will abide by international lenders' strictures.

headline: Detroiters Air Gripes
summary: Mayor Dave Bing's campaign to reconcile Detroit's sprawling land mass with its shrinking population got off to a shaky start, turning up more signs of the daunting challenge he faces.

headline: Attacks, Threats Deter Afghan Voters
summary: Turnout was low in Afghan parliamentary elections as attacks by Taliban insurgents killed at least 14 people and forced hundreds of polling stations to close.

headline: The Pope's Third Day in Britain
summary: Pope Benedict XVI expressed "deep sorrow" for victims of clerical sex-abuse during a Mass Saturday at Westminster Cathedral in London.

headline: Obama Warns on Attack Ads
summary: Barack Obama again criticized Republican leaders in Congress for blocking a campaign finance proposal and warned Americans to view political attack ads with caution.

headline: Shaft Reaches Chile Miners
summary: Rescuers drilled a foot-wide borehole through to the part of a collapsed mine where 33 miners have been trapped for six weeks, marking an advance in rescue efforts.

headline: Hurdles for Warren in Agency Launch
summary: Elizabeth Warren faces logistical, legal and political challenges as she attempts to build credibility for the new Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection.

headline: City Budget Mess Leads to Ghost Day Care
summary: Paterson signed an amendment requiring the city to give six months' notice for day-care closures. That means the six centers scheduled to shutter are open until March. But it was too late for most families.

headline: A Game of Emotional Distress
summary: As the Ryder Cup approaches, thoughts on how to cure a slump.

headline: Pelosi Facing Dissent in Party
summary: Swing-district Democrats, many of whom are fighting for their political lives, have started to turn against House Speaker Pelosi.

headline: Braves 6, Mets 4
summary: Mets starter Jon Niese, handed a three-run lead in the team's 6-4 loss to the Braves on Friday, did all of the following with two outs in the fourth inning: allowed an RBI single to Melky Cabrera (Atlanta's No. 8 hitter), walked Tommy Hanson (the opposing pitcher), then surrendered a two-run double to Omar Infante and a three-run home run to Jason Heyward.

headline: Capitol Grilling Could Burn Slabs
summary: Student-loan asset-backed securities could suffer big losses if political scrutiny of for-profit education companies leads to tough legislation.

headline: Donnie Baseball To Replace Joe Torre
summary: The Dodgers announce Don Mattingly will replace Joe Torre as manager. The Jets announce it will institute a league-wide training program. And Minaya will discuss the life and career of Roberto Clemente.

headline: The Art of the Book
summary: Robbin Ami Silverberg runs a papermaking studio in Williamsburg, where she grows plants, presses them into paper, binds the books and inscribes the text. She's a book artist, but also part chemist and artisan.

headline: Numbers That Make Sense of the Market
summary: Three easily followed indicators can help you make sense of today's chaotic, macro-driven trading environment—and maybe even get out in front of the next big move.

headline: Kohl's Mines for Market Share
summary: Kohl's has outpaced rivals in good and bad times alike, and there is reason to think the retailer will continue that performance.

headline: Route to Citizenship in Defense Bill
summary: The Senate is expected to consider giving illegal immigrants who go to college or join the military a pathway to citizenship as part of the big defense-authorization bill.

headline: Why I Hate Ordering Wine by the Glass
summary: Do the math. Think about where it's been. The problem of pouring one at a time, and how to fix it.

headline: Noda Says Japan May Act Again
summary: Japan's finance minister threatened to intervene in the foreign-exchange market again if necessary, signaling Tokyo's resolve to defend its export-led economy despite criticism from abroad.

headline: Swedes May Usher In Anti-Immigrant Party
summary: A Swedish anti-immigrant party is expected to win its first-ever parliamentary seats in elections Sunday, the latest example of rising anti-immigrant sentiment in Europe.

headline: H-P Scans Own Offices for New CEO
summary: Hewlett-Packard's board is moving closer to naming a new chief executive and would prefer to pick a candidate from within the company.

headline: Predictions: Giants 28, Patriots 27
summary: While the focus heading into Super Bowl XLVI is, as always, on the quarterback matchup, the game is never quarterback versus quarterback, but quarterback versus defense.

summary: Football can be broken down very neatly into specific situations and matchups, so we decided to build a statistical model that will help us predict who will win as we go through the season.

headline: Technology Firms Lift Stocks
summary: Stocks climbed narrowly into positive territory, as technology companies added to the week's modest gains.

headline: Pension Gaps Loom Larger
summary: Many of America's largest pension funds are sticking to expectations of fat returns on their investments even after a decade of paltry gains, which could leave the U.S. with an even larger pensions shortfall than expected.

headline: Five Best World War II Memoirs
summary: British historian Andrew Roberts ("Masters and Commanders") on outstanding first-hand accounts of World War II.

headline: Citadel Discusses Fees, Redemptions
summary: Hedge-fund manager Citadel is in preliminary talks with a few investors on reducing management fees and allowing easier redemptions for its two flagship funds.

headline: This Week
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase's 16 million online-banking customers lost access to their accounts for at least 28 hours from Monday through Wednesday.

headline: Zimbabwe to Overhaul Central Bank
summary: Zimbabwe's central bank is broke, dysfunctional and the custodian of a currency that officially no longer exists. But it has a comeback plan that it hopes will help spur growth.

headline: Think Before Selling Life Insurance
summary: Many older adults are considering selling their life-insurance policies to strangers in order to shore up their finances. The strategy, though, might not make as much sense as it did a few years ago.

headline: Jeter Says Criticism Of Him Unjustified
summary: Yankees captain says his actng job came after the home-plate umpire had ruled that he was hit by a pitch. He just didn't want the umpire to reverse the call.

headline: Our Guide to Famous Brothers
summary: How does the Peyton and Eli Manning rivalry compare with those of other famous brothers?

headline: Social Conservatives Eye Tea-Party Seat
summary: Tea-party favorite Christine O'Donnell's appearance at the Values Voter Summit highlights the challenge facing social conservatives as they try to hitch themselves to the fiscal insurgents of 2010.

summary: An illustrator finds a new calling by photographing a miniature World War II world he created after suffering a traumatic head injury.

summary: The president of Sharp criticized the Japanese government for failing to create a better environment for "fair international competition."

headline: Fund: What on Earth Happened to the New York GOP?
summary: A dozen years ago Republicans dominated state politics. It doesn't appear they'll be a factor this fall.

summary: Treasurys prices rose as the latest U.S. reports on inflation and consumer sentiment raised worries about deflation and the health of the economy.

summary: The Taliban stepped up their campaign to disrupt Afghanistan's parliamentary elections, kidnapping two candidates and several electoral workers a day ahead of the Sept. 18 vote.

summary: Government agencies increasingly are putting out report cards for cars, schools, restaurants and other offerings to help consumers sort among them. But such report cards can emphasize simplicity over precision.

headline: Bicycle Mischief Targets Barclays
summary: British bank Barclays, which sponsors London's new public bike-rental program, became the target of vandalism as obscene stickers were affixed to a number of the rental bicycles.

summary: The Chiefs' quarterback problems are well known—they'll start either Tyler Palko or Kyle Orton against the Jets on Sunday—but Kansas City has defensive issues, too.

summary: Citigroup is selling its 80% stake in Student Loan Corp. to Discover Financial Services as part of a $600 million transaction that marks the bank's biggest step to shed noncore assets.

summary: Two former New York City employees were sentenced to prison Friday for stealing and selling the identification documents that their city department jobs gave them regular access to.

summary: The SEC voted 5-0 in favor of proposing rules that would heighten disclosure connected to some banks' practice of curtailing debt at the end of a quarter.

summary: The merger of UAL's United Airlines and Continental Airlines cleared its last big hurdle when shareholders of both companies approved the deal by a wide margin.

headline: Sentimental for a Good Pen Name
summary: In "Politics and the Cult of Sentimentality" (op-ed, Sept. 8) Theodore Dalrymple links sentimentality to self love. The cause of modern sentimentality is our increased wealth, which gives us the leisure to posture on behalf of others to enhance our own reputations.

headline: Massacres Shake Rwanda's U.N. Role
summary: A U.N. draft report accusing Rwanda's army of killing tens of thousands of refugees in the 1990s has threatened to jeopardize Rwanda's support for U.N. peacekeeping operations.

summary: In "Bink & Gollie," Kate DiCamillo and Alison McGhee present a trio of stories about two girls who might be unlike--short and loud versus tall and austere—but remain devoted friends. Meghan Cox Gurdon reviews.

headline: Luxury Home Exits Housing Court

summary: Protesters torched vehicles and markets in Pakistan's largest city after a senior politician from the local ruling party was stabbed to death in London.

summary: The International Monetary Fund said Friday that it doesn't think Ireland will need financial assistance from the institution.

headline: Six Banks Fail, Marking 125 for 2010

headline: Neighborhoods Saw Out After Tornado
summary: The storm was over in less than 30 minutes, but it left one dead, more than 40,000 without electricity, thousands of commuters stranded and thousands of trees downed.

headline: A New Wrinkle in Options
summary: Short-term weekly option contracts are gaining traction among investors—even though their higher volatility can make it much easier to lose money.

headline: Classics Have Added Value Over Time
summary: James Piereson "Where Columbia Beats Harvard" (Taste, Sept. 3) argues that Harvard's undergraduate curricula differs from that of Columbia's since it needs to be constantly revised in order to ". . . keep pace with changing conditions." Columbia's curricula, on the other hand ". . .  are organized around timeless themes expressed in works that are unlikely to go out of style."

headline: The U.S. Hardly Needs to Have an Industrial Policy
summary: Jeremy Weisen discusses an industrial policy for the U.S. that would include funding by the government of projects that would encourage entrepreneurial activity ("The U.S. Needs Its Own Industrial Policy," op-ed,  Sept. 13).

summary: IBM has entered into an in-principle agreement to manage Indian telecommunications-services provider Bharti Airtel's technology operations in 16 African countries.

summary: Microsoft said a long-awaited operating system for smartphones initially won't be available on handsets compatible with Verizon Wireless and Sprint Nextel.

Ah, for the happy days of 1999, when IPOs were a path to instant riches. Take VA Software, whose stock soared 700% on its first day of trading. How times have changed: Dealogic says the average one-day return on U.S. IPOs year to date is a meager 5%, the lowest on record.

summary: House lawmakers have left Washington without scheduling an ethics trial for Rep. Charles Rangel, suggesting the public hearings almost certainly won't begin until after the November midterm elections.

summary: No matter how ugly, a win is a win, and the Jets snapped their three-game losing streak with a convincing, if uninspiring, home victory over the Dolphins.

summary: Bassist Mark Ibold and his group play Central Park as part of their reunion tour.

summary: The Giants face the Redskins—after losing to Washington in Week 1—and the Jets take on the Eagles.
